p: The evidence for associations of Lyme disease risk in eastern Canada with climate comes from studies of the spatial patterns of tick, pathogen, and human Lyme disease case occurrence. These also served to “detect” the phenomenon of Lyme disease emergence in southern Canada. Temperature increase was considered a key driver of emergence, with this temperature change attributed to climate change ( Vincent et al. 2012), while other possible drivers of emergence such as habitat change were ruled out over most of the affected area ( Ogden et al. 2014).
